sourceDesc:
<<<<<<< HEAD
The foūtayne or well of lyfe, out of whiche doth sprynge mooste swete consolations, ryght necessarye for troubled conscyences to thyntente they shal not despayre in aduersitie and trouble..
Newly corrected and amended..
[144] p.
By William Hill at y[e] Signe of the hyll., Jmprented at London : [1548 or 1549].
Initial. Imprint from colophon; date of publication suggested by STC (2nd ed.). Signatures: A-I⁸. Imperfect: stained, torn, and tightly bound, with loss of text; opening of A₅v and A₆r not filmed. Reproduction of original in: National Library of Scotland.
=======
The foūtayne or well of lyfe, out of whiche doth sprynge mooste swete consolations, ryght necessarye for troubled conscyences to thyntente they shal not despayre in aduersitie and trouble..
Newly corrected and amended..
[144] p.
By William Hill at y[e] Signe of the hyll., Jmprented at London : [1548 or 1549].
Initial. Imprint from colophon; date of publication suggested by STC (2nd ed.). Signatures: A-I⁸. Imperfect: stained, torn, and tightly bound, with loss of text; opening of A₅v and A₆r not filmed. Reproduction of original in: National Library of Scotland.
William Hill
y[e] Signe of the hyll.
>>>>>>> imprintparse
